Well, the problem here is that you haven't defined what kind of distance you're measuring. If you measurse linear distance (measured in centimeters), then going from 12 to 6 gets you further and further away from 12, but if you're measuring angular distance (measured in degrees), then, yes, you could say you're getting closer and further away at the same time.
This all depends on what distance we're talking about. Is the distance in a straight or is it the distance along the edge of the circle?

thanks for this information... English is not my native language so I didn't know that

Yes you are. As far as you get from the 12 from the one side, you are getting closer to it from the other side. When the distance between two things decreases, they are getting closer — whether you're halfway there is irrelevant.
No, because the distance between them on the other side is decreasing. It doesn't matter how much of the Earth's circumference the distance is, if it is decreasing, they are getting closer.
Also, the Earth *is* round. It's just not spherical. "Round" is not a synonym for "spherical".
Actually, you *do* get closer to it from the other side. However much farther you get from the 12 in one direction, you get closer to it in the other direction.
How did he prove your point?

that they're moving away from each other does not say that happens towards one side or another, they are actually going outwards

No no, say you were only moving one way and the other didn't exist. You would be moving closer. Even though you're moving further, still your moving closer. Even if the six weren't there. Despite the fact that it's round, Still, it's getting closer since in one perspective you are.
Hmm, yeah, I guess you're right.  I apologize for my mistake.

what?... just take a meter, please :( .... as long as you are moving from 12 to 6 (or from 3 to 6, does not matter) you are getting further and further from 12. You are not getting any closer until you pass the 6.
I don't quite follow your logic.  If you are moving towards 6, then 12 would be getting closer also.

no, if you are moving towards 6 and measuring your distance from 12, it is getting bigger and bigger. It actually more depends on our way of thinking about the ball. If we apply our theory on the surface of the ball ONLY, then yes, you are moving closer and further at the same time

It all depends on perspective. Say you were small enough to stand on the hand as it moved around.  If you looked out towards 3 it would appear that you were moving away from 12. But if you looked out towards 6 it would appear that you were moving closer to 12.
